credential_theft.title: Password Compromised
credential_theft.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. Let's secure your accounts right away.

steps.title: Change the compromised password immediately
steps.description: Go to the real website of the service (type the URL yourself) and change your password to something new and unique.
steps.help_detail: Use a password that is at least 12 characters long with a mix of letters, numbers, and symbols. Do not reuse passwords across sites.

steps.title: Enable two-factor authentication
steps.description: Turn on two-factor authentication (2FA) on the compromised account and any account that used the same password.
steps.help_detail: 2FA adds an extra step when logging in, like a code sent to your phone. This makes it much harder for someone else to access your account even if they have your password.

steps.title: Check for unauthorized activity
steps.description: Review recent activity on the compromised account. Look for logins you don't recognize, messages you didn't send, or settings changes you didn't make.
steps.help_detail: Most services have a 'Recent Activity' or 'Security' section in settings where you can see login history.

steps.title: Change password on other accounts using the same password
steps.description: If you used the same password on other accounts, change those passwords now too.
steps.help_detail: Attackers often try stolen passwords on many popular services like email, banking, and social media.

steps.title: Monitor your accounts for the next 30 days
steps.description: Keep an eye on your accounts over the next month for any unusual activity.
steps.help_detail: Set up login alerts if the service offers them. This will notify you whenever someone logs into your account.

financial_fraud.title: Financial Information Exposed
financial_fraud.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. Time is important, so let's start with the most urgent step.

steps.title: Call your bank or credit card company immediately
steps.description: Report the incident and ask them to freeze or block the compromised card or account.
steps.help_detail: The number is on the back of your card or on your bank statement. Tell them you may have shared your information with a fraudulent website.

steps.title: Monitor your account for unauthorized transactions
steps.description: Check your recent transactions and report any you don't recognize to your bank.
steps.help_detail: Your bank may be able to reverse unauthorized charges if reported quickly.

steps.title: Place a fraud alert on your credit report
steps.description: Contact one of the three credit bureaus to place a fraud alert. They will notify the other two.
steps.help_detail: Call Equifax (800-525-6285), Experian (888-397-3742), or TransUnion (800-680-7289).

steps.title: Report the fraud to the FTC
steps.description: File a report at reportfraud.ftc.gov or call 877-382-4357.
steps.help_detail: The FTC report creates an official record and can help with disputing fraudulent charges.

steps.title: Change online banking passwords
steps.description: Update your passwords for online banking and any financial apps.
steps.help_detail: Use a strong, unique password and enable two-factor authentication if available.

steps.title: Continue monitoring for 90 days
steps.description: Watch your accounts and credit reports closely for the next 3 months.
steps.help_detail: Consider signing up for free credit monitoring through your bank or a service like Credit Karma.

identity_theft.title: Personal Information Exposed
identity_theft.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. Protecting your identity is the priority.

steps.title: Place a credit freeze with all three bureaus
steps.description: A credit freeze prevents anyone from opening new accounts in your name.
steps.help_detail: Contact Equifax (800-525-6285), Experian (888-397-3742), and TransUnion (800-680-7289). A freeze is free and does not affect your credit score.

steps.title: Report identity theft to the FTC
steps.description: Visit IdentityTheft.gov to file an official report and get a personalized recovery plan.
steps.help_detail: The FTC report is an official document that can help you dispute fraudulent accounts.

steps.title: Contact the Social Security Administration if SSN was shared
steps.description: Call the SSA at 800-772-1213 to report potential misuse of your Social Security number.
steps.help_detail: The SSA can flag your account and help you monitor for fraudulent use.

steps.title: File a police report
steps.description: Contact your local police department and file a report. Keep the report number.
steps.help_detail: A police report can help when disputing fraudulent accounts with creditors.

steps.title: Monitor your credit and accounts for 90 days
steps.description: Check your credit reports weekly and watch for any accounts or inquiries you don't recognize.
steps.help_detail: You can get free weekly credit reports at AnnualCreditReport.com.

malware_download.title: Suspicious Download
malware_download.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. Let's secure your device first.

steps.title: Disconnect from the internet
steps.description: Turn off Wi-Fi and mobile data on the affected device to prevent the software from communicating with attackers.
steps.help_detail: You can also enable airplane mode. This stops any malware from sending your data or downloading more harmful files.

steps.title: Delete the downloaded file
steps.description: Find and delete the file you downloaded. Check your Downloads folder.
steps.help_detail: On iPhone, check Files app. On Android, check Downloads folder. On a computer, check your Downloads folder and also empty the trash/recycle bin.

steps.title: Run a device security scan
steps.description: Use your device's built-in security scanner or a trusted antivirus app to scan for threats.
steps.help_detail: On Android, open Google Play Protect from the Play Store. On iPhone, Apple's built-in protections are automatic. On a computer, run Windows Defender or your installed antivirus.

steps.title: Update your device software
steps.description: Install any available updates for your operating system and apps.
steps.help_detail: Updates often contain security fixes that protect against known threats.

steps.title: Change important passwords from a different device
steps.description: Using a different, clean device, change passwords for your email, banking, and other important accounts.
steps.help_detail: If the downloaded file was malware, it may have captured passwords you typed on the affected device.

gift_card_wire.title: Money Sent to Scammer
gift_card_wire.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. Let's see if we can recover any of the funds.

steps.title: Contact the gift card issuer or payment provider immediately
steps.description: If you sent gift cards, call the number on the back of the card and report the fraud. If you sent a wire transfer, contact your bank or the wire service.
steps.help_detail: Some gift card companies may be able to freeze remaining funds. For wire transfers, contact your bank immediately — there is sometimes a short window to reverse transfers.

steps.title: Save all evidence
steps.description: Keep the gift cards, receipts, any messages or emails from the scammer, and records of the transaction.
steps.help_detail: This evidence will be needed for filing reports with law enforcement and the FTC.

steps.title: File a report with the FTC
steps.description: Report the scam at reportfraud.ftc.gov.
steps.help_detail: The FTC uses reports to build cases against scammers and alert others about emerging scam types.

steps.title: File a police report
steps.description: Contact your local police and file a report. Keep the case number.
steps.help_detail: While recovery of gift card funds is difficult, police reports create an official record.

steps.title: Report to the FBI's IC3
steps.description: File a report at ic3.gov if the total amount lost exceeds $1,000.
steps.help_detail: The Internet Crime Complaint Center tracks and investigates internet fraud.

remote_access.title: Device Remote Access Given
remote_access.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. Let's secure your device immediately.

steps.title: Disconnect from the internet immediately
steps.description: Turn off Wi-Fi and mobile data. This cuts the attacker's access to your device.
steps.help_detail: Pull the ethernet cable if on a desktop. Enable airplane mode on a phone or tablet.

steps.title: Uninstall the remote access software
steps.description: Remove any remote access applications that were installed (AnyDesk, TeamViewer, LogMeIn, etc.).
steps.help_detail: On a phone, long-press the app icon and uninstall. On a computer, go to Settings > Apps and uninstall.

steps.title: Change all passwords from a different, clean device
steps.description: Using a different device, change passwords for your email, banking, social media, and any other important accounts.
steps.help_detail: The attacker may have seen or captured passwords while they had access to your device. Start with email and banking.

steps.title: Call your bank
steps.description: If you accessed any financial services while the attacker had remote access, call your bank to report it.
steps.help_detail: The attacker may have seen account numbers, balances, or login credentials.

steps.title: Run a full security scan
steps.description: Reconnect to the internet and run a full antivirus scan of your device.
steps.help_detail: The attacker may have installed additional software during their access.

steps.title: Consider a factory reset
steps.description: For maximum safety, consider performing a factory reset of the affected device.
steps.help_detail: A factory reset removes everything the attacker may have installed. Back up important files first if possible (use a different device to verify they are not infected).

general_unknown.title: General Safety Precautions
general_unknown.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. Let's take some precautionary steps.

steps.title: Change your most important passwords
steps.description: Start with your email, then banking and financial accounts, then social media.
steps.help_detail: Use a unique, strong password for each account. Consider using a password manager.

steps.title: Enable two-factor authentication
steps.description: Turn on 2FA on your email and banking accounts.
steps.help_detail: This adds an extra security layer that protects your accounts even if someone has your password.

steps.title: Monitor your accounts
steps.description: Check your email, bank, and social media accounts for any unusual activity over the next few weeks.
steps.help_detail: Look for logins you don't recognize, messages you didn't send, or charges you didn't make.

steps.title: Run a device security scan
steps.description: Use your device's built-in security features to scan for threats.
steps.help_detail: On Android, use Google Play Protect. On a computer, run your antivirus software.

blackmail_sextortion.title: Blackmail or Sextortion Email
blackmail_sextortion.opening_message: Don't worry — these emails are almost always bluffs. Let's walk through what to do.

steps.title: Do not pay
steps.description: These emails are almost always mass-sent bluffs. The sender typically does not have the data or footage they claim. Paying encourages further extortion and does not guarantee the threats will stop.
steps.help_detail: These scammers send the same threatening email to thousands of people hoping a few will pay out of fear. The vast majority have no actual compromising material.

steps.title: Do not reply or engage
steps.description: Any response confirms your email is active and may lead to escalated demands.
steps.help_detail: Scammers track which emails get responses. Replying — even to say 'leave me alone' — tells them they have a responsive target.

steps.title: Check if a password was included
steps.description: If the email includes one of your passwords, it likely came from an old data breach. Change that password immediately on any account where you still use it.
steps.help_detail: You can check if your email has been in a data breach at haveibeenpwned.com.

steps.title: Enable two-factor authentication
steps.description: Turn on 2FA for your email and any accounts referenced in the message.
steps.help_detail: This prevents anyone from accessing your accounts even if they have an old password.

steps.title: Mark the email as spam/phishing
steps.description: Mark the email as spam or phishing in your email client to help train filters.
steps.help_detail: In Gmail, click the three dots and select 'Report phishing.' In Outlook, use 'Report message' > 'Phishing.'

steps.title: Report the email
steps.description: Report to the FTC (reportfraud.ftc.gov) and the FBI's IC3 (ic3.gov) if financial demands were made.
steps.help_detail: Reporting helps authorities track and shut down these operations.

steps.title: If you already paid, contact your bank
steps.description: Contact your bank or payment provider immediately. If you paid via cryptocurrency, file a report but be aware recovery is unlikely.
steps.help_detail: Some payment methods may allow chargebacks or reversals if reported quickly.

ransomware_extortion.title: Ransomware Threat
ransomware_extortion.opening_message: Don't worry — let's figure out if this is real and what to do next.

steps.title: Do not pay the ransom
steps.description: Payment does not guarantee file recovery and funds criminal operations.
steps.help_detail: The FBI and cybersecurity experts advise against paying ransoms. Many victims who pay never receive working decryption keys.

steps.title: Verify the claim
steps.description: Many ransomware emails are bluffs with no actual encryption. Check whether you can still access your files normally. If your files open fine, the email is a scam — delete it.
steps.help_detail: Try opening several different files (documents, photos) in different folders. If everything works normally, the email is a bluff.

steps.title: If files are actually encrypted: disconnect immediately
steps.description: Disconnect the affected device from Wi-Fi and all networks to prevent spread to other devices.
steps.help_detail: Unplug ethernet cables, turn off Wi-Fi, and disconnect any external drives or shared network folders.

steps.title: Do not attempt to decrypt files with unknown tools
steps.description: Some 'decryption tools' found online are themselves malware.
steps.help_detail: Only use tools from trusted sources like the No More Ransom project.

steps.title: Check No More Ransom
steps.description: Visit nomoreransom.org — a free, legitimate resource with decryption tools for many known ransomware strains.
steps.help_detail: This project is run by law enforcement and cybersecurity companies. It has helped hundreds of thousands of victims decrypt their files for free.

steps.title: Report the incident
steps.description: Report to the FBI's IC3 (ic3.gov) and your local law enforcement.
steps.help_detail: Reporting helps authorities track ransomware groups and may eventually lead to free decryption tools.

steps.title: Restore from backup
steps.description: If you have backups, restore your files from the most recent clean backup.
steps.help_detail: If you don't have backups, consult a professional data recovery service. After recovery, establish a regular backup routine.

steps.title: After recovery: full scan and update
steps.description: Run a full device scan, update all software, and establish a regular backup routine.
steps.help_detail: Consider automatic cloud backups to protect against future incidents.

pig_butchering.title: Romance-Investment Scam
pig_butchering.opening_message: Don't worry — let's fix this together. The most important thing is to stop further losses.

steps.title: Stop all further payments immediately
steps.description: No matter what the other person says, do not send any additional money. Claims that 'one more payment will unlock your funds' are part of the scam.
steps.help_detail: Scammers are experts at creating urgency and emotional pressure. Any request for more money at this point is guaranteed to be fraudulent.

steps.title: Accept that the relationship is likely part of the scam
steps.description: This is difficult but important. Pig butchering scams deliberately build emotional trust over weeks or months before introducing the investment component.
steps.help_detail: The person you've been communicating with is almost certainly not who they claim to be. These scams often use stolen photos and scripted conversations run by organized crime groups.

steps.title: Document everything
steps.description: Save all messages, transaction records, screenshots of the investment platform, and any contact details for the other person.
steps.help_detail: Take screenshots before the scammer deletes messages or the platform disappears. This evidence is critical for law enforcement.

steps.title: Contact your bank or financial institution
steps.description: Report the transactions. Some transfers may be reversible depending on timing and method.
steps.help_detail: Wire transfers may be recoverable if reported within 24-72 hours. Credit card charges can often be disputed. Cryptocurrency transfers are generally not recoverable.

steps.title: Report to the FTC and FBI
steps.description: File reports at reportfraud.ftc.gov, ic3.gov, and your state attorney general's office.
steps.help_detail: These agencies track fraud patterns and occasionally recover funds from scam operations.

steps.title: Report the fraudulent investment platform
steps.description: Report to the SEC (sec.gov/tcr) or CFTC if cryptocurrency was involved.
steps.help_detail: The SEC investigates fraudulent investment platforms and can take action to shut them down.

steps.title: Report the scammer's profile
steps.description: Report the profile on the dating app or social media platform where you met them.
steps.help_detail: This helps platforms remove scam profiles and protect other potential victims.

steps.title: Beware of recovery scams
steps.description: After being scammed, victims are often targeted by people claiming they can recover lost funds for a fee. These are also scams.
steps.help_detail: Legitimate law enforcement and regulatory agencies do not charge fees to help fraud victims.

steps.title: Consider speaking with a counselor
steps.description: Pig butchering victims often experience significant emotional distress. AARP's fraud helpline (877-908-3360) provides free support.
steps.help_detail: There is no shame in being a victim of these scams. They are run by sophisticated criminal organizations that deliberately exploit human emotions.
